title: Who will be elected governor of Kentucky in the 2019 gubernatorial election?
possible_answers: Andy Beshear (Democrat) by a margin greater than 5.00% of the total vote
Andy Beshear (Democrat) by a margin of 5.00% or less of the total vote
Matt Bevin (Republican) by a margin of 5.00% or less of the total vote
Matt Bevin (Republican) by a margin greater than 5.00% of the total vote
correct_answer: Andy Beshear (Democrat) by a margin of 5.00% or less of the total vote
preds: The polls are tied.  This is a very tough question, which is why I decided to try it.   The governor is very unpopular.  The challenger is more popular.  In the most recent debate, the Republican governor dropped his anti-Trump impeachment attacks on his Democratic challenger.   I doubt he would have done that unless his internal polls said the issue was not helping him.   The summary of the most recent debate suggests that Beshear has a more appealing economic message and Bevin might be  stronger on  Kentucky social issues.   Bevin has closed an 8-point gap in the last few weeks so the trend is in his direction, and he recently pumped in another $900k of his own money into his  campaign.   All in all I  suspect that Bevin is the likely winner.
Candidates are being drowned out by PAC money. No way to influence the middle ...

Crowd: 4%, 46%, 47%, 3%, 0% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1810547132

Updated model [1] with most recent PredictIt numbers and new October poll. Model: 6%, 25%, 69%, 0%, 0%
Crowd: 4%, 44%, 47%, 4%, 1% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1810547132

Two weeks to go and the Courier Journal opines "that we've seen this before" - in this case a 9 point poll lead for the Democrat Beshear drifting into what could be a dead heat, leading to a Republican win for reasons consistent with KY voting patterns in the past.
Not being familiar with KY state politics - I find this instructive enough to adjust percentages, with Beshear still winning due to expected mobilized turnout, family political machine, and the unlike-ability of the opponent Bevin.

Mason Dixon poll is a pretty reliable one per FiveThirtyEight assessment.
M-D had Beshear leading by 8 points in Dec - and now tied with Bevin.
Two polls were done in August showing Beshear in the lead.
One poll in June had it the other way.
To me, this is noteworthy to find on the eve of decision-making as voters "firm up".
Bevin's unfavorability, to me, still gives Beshear the lead.
There are about 22k more Republicans than Democrats in Kentucky

Updated model [1] with most recent PredictIt numbers. No new polls to incorporate. Model: 16%, 20%, 64%, 0%, 0%
Crowd: 9%, 39%, 43%, 9%, 1% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1810547132
I think this election seems to be pretty much a toss-up.
Most recently available polls appear to show partisan bias. If the D-affiliated polling is accurate, then Beshear is more likely to win by a close margin of less than 5%.

Finally got some comparative polling data:
Mason-Dixon: Dec 2018 --- Beshear over Bevin by 8 points
Gravis Marketing; June 2019 ---Bevin over Beshear by 6 points
Clarity Campaign: Aug 2019---Beshear over Bevin by 9 points
Garin-Hart: Aug 2019---- Beshear over Bevin by 9 points I can't opine on their rigor - or the margin of error -  I am assuming +-3%.
The first and last pollsters did get B+ ratings from Five-Thirty-Eight, each with an indication of slightly predictive scoring.
Enough for me to now have to consider a +5 win by Beshear, and to raise his overall chances of winning.

The historical data suggests a victory for Beshear. The Republicans have only won 2 of the last 8 gubernatorial elections in Kentucky. This is though, in contrast to 2015 when the Republicans recorded a convincing victory. History seems to favour the Democrats then. Furthermore, the current governor Matt Bevan is very unpopular and has not done well in recent polls. Considering the historical dominance of the Democrats and how unpopular Bevan is I'm going to say that the Democrats have a 60% chance of winning. I have indicated that there is good chance of a big win either way because the margin of victory has been more than 5% in 7 of the last 8 gubernatorial elections.

Updated model [1] with most recent PredictIt numbers. No new polls to incorporate. Model: 18%, 23%, 59%, 0%, 0%
Crowd: 8%, 26%, 52%, 12%, 2% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1810547132

Heavily Republican state presently.
20+ year history of Democratic governors, though. Bevin recently fired his campaign manager after the empty-arena event with Trump Jr. in early September.
For this to occur so late in the game - i have to wonder if the world for Bevin is not as it was in 2015.
Bevin beat his primary challenger 52% to 39% in 2019 - so he seems well situated within his own party. 
And he won the 2015 election handily; 52% to 43%.
But his issues with teachers have followed him throughout his tenure - particularly on pensions.
And he's received some bipartisan shade in the Legislature. 
I also wonder about his general likability - trending 56% disapproval/32% approval can't be helpful. Andy Beshear is current AG.
Son of former 2- term governor Steve Beshear, who was termed out in 2015.
The Beshears seem to be a prominent KY political family.
He received one cross-party endorsement in July.
He will need cross-over voters.
He is using the teachers' treatment as cause for a One Kentucky kind of platform. Given the family history in KY, and the unlike-ability of the present Governor, balanced against a heavily Red state - Beshear the unlikely winner - but a squeaker.

Updating model [1] with current PredictIt. Also using different poll aggregation source (Wikipedia instead of RCP) which has more recent polls (thanks for the tip @ccorcoran223). Crowd: 8%, 27%, 51%, 12%, 2% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE

This race is a tossup because both of them are pretty close to each other and far away from other candidates. In this kind of scenario, based on experience in other regions,  as the election nears, we can see lot of attacks flying everywhere. However, Matt has some additional advantage of majority in house, Senate, demographics and fact that he is current governor, he is leading the race on background scale.

The race is moving in Beshear's direction based on expert race ratings and there hasn't been a poll since June. Bevin isn't particularly popular while Beshear is the son of a recent governor. Both have shown they can win statewide office so I think the race is a tossup right now but will be close either way. Leaning slightly toward Bevin for the incumbency advantage.

The base rate for democratic governors in KY since 1990 is ~50%, and for statewide elections it's more like 33%. Since KY is trending towards its conservatism manifesting in republican voting, the latter figure is probably better. But, Bevin is highly unpopular, other statewide republicans are unpopular, there's an unusual amount of democratic funding, there's an unusual amount of democratic talent in the form of Beshear and McGrath, the polls are tied, Beshear is winning on endorsements, and Cook et al. labels the race a tossup. Arguments for Bevin seem only to be incumbency, down-ballot voting (which matters less outside of prez elections, where Trump may have been the biggest help), a reasonably good economy, and a possible KY polling skew towards Democrats. So, I think all of this revises the 33% up to 40%. Kentucky's governor results widely, so I gave the distributions fat tails. Beyond those descriptors, this is guesswork.

The republicans have lost 2 out of 7 of the gubernatorial elections since 1992. Before then the Democratic party in the South was very very different in outlook and composition, which is why I am starting from there.  Bevin the republican incumbent, is *very* unpopular, with 50% of voters disapproving of him since Q2 2018. Ernie Fletcher, the republican governor who lost in 2007 was also incredibly unpopular, not polling above 40% in all of that election year. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Kentucky_gubernatorial_election)

Incumbency and partisan lean. Offsetting this (and giving Beshear a shot) is his popularity (and Bevin's unpopularity) and the history of Democratic governors. But, I think national partisanship will likely trump that (pun intended).

After seeing how unpopular Bevin is compared to other governors, I view this race as a tossup.  Bevin's unpopularity seems balanced against his incumbency, Republican party, Trump positive approval, etc

There don't appear to be any good polling data.  Incumbent gubernatorial candidates appear to have a pretty high probability of winning.  Combined with Kentucky being a red state, but offset by Bevin's unpopularity, I only give him slightly higher odds of beating Andy Beshear.   Trump's positive net approval in Kentucky also gives the edge to Bevin
Election markets have republicans as favourite, polls have been inconclusive, incumbent is unpopular and democrats have a history of doing well in gubernatorial elections in Kentucky.

Kentucky is a Red state that has a history of Blue governors. Bevin's predecessor was Beshear Sr who was liked and jr is a respected Atty General. Coal mining has declined causing economic hardships in Kentucky despite an overall economic upward trend nation wide under the Trump administration. McConnell is associated with Deripaska for circumventing Russian sanctions to create/ invest in Braidy aluminum plant in Kentucky touted by Bevin, to help local Kentucky residents obtain jobs.   Kentucky is also dead center to tornadoes going straight through Paducah, so any negative experience with FEMA/Emergency Services and financial losses adds to Democratic talking points for attempts to increase votes by blaming existing Republican leadership. The problem of soybeans--2017 was supposed to be record year for Kentucky, but we all know how that went with China trade wars https://agfax.com/2017/08/15/kentucky-soybeans-record-high-potential-exists-for-2017-production/ and tobacco isn't what it was in 1960 due to decline in health reasons. Kentucky favored blue governors in the past and with anti Trump rhetoric there is a chance, however with popular Republicans on the ticket such as Rand Paul and many straight party voters, Republicans (assuming they don't mess up) will prevail with a narrow margin of victory. With this being said, Nov 2019 is a long ways off and a lot can happen between now and then to change public opinion causing votes to be changed. While its basically a toss up, there is a slight lean toward Republicans to maintain the Governorship with the current incumbent.
I agree with the modelling results of @dglid

Simple model [1] using implied probability from PredictIt [2] for likelihood of Dem vs GOP win, then calculating margin of victory based on latest poll spread including margin of error from RCP [3]. Latest poll is from June, so might be missing something here, but happy enough with this for now.
